Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Collaborative Research: COVID-19 Preparedness in Remote Fishing Communities in Rural Alaska
Award.AbstractNarration: This time-sensitive RAPID project focuses on perception of COVID-19 risk in the Bristol Bay region of rural western Alaska. Every spring, the town of Dillingham, the hub of Bristol Bay fisheries, experiences massive in-migration, as an estimated 13,000 workers arrive for the sockeye salmon fishing season. Local health care resources and access to transportation are extremely limited. Leveraging existing partnerships, project investigators will conduct surveys with local residents, decision makers, fishermen and processors to characterize risk perception, evaluate social distancing compliance, and assess perceived costs and benefits of various pandemic mitigation plans. These data will inform epidemiological modeling of possible scenarios in the region and help stakeholders understand the dynamics of COVID-19 in a transient population working in the close quarters of fishing vessels and the crowded conditions of fish processing plants. This project will contribute to the emerging body of research on the perception and effects of COVID-19 across the country, and more specifically, to understanding pandemic impacts on a key Alaska industry.<br/><br/>Standard ethnographic methods, including qualitative key informant interviews, two online surveys, and collection of cell phone mobility data, will be employed to characterize risk perception and response and evaluate compliance with social distancing guidelines. Surveys will be designed collaboratively, and will leverage existing networks developed as part of an ongoing Navigating the New Arctic project (ICER 1927827). Surveys will be conducted at the beginning of the 2020 fishing season and again in February/March 2021. Analysis will evaluate risk perception and response by occupation, socioeconomic status, age, and sex. Epidemiological modeling will be employed to predict disease dynamics (i.e., likelihood of infection and mortality) under different scenarios; these estimates will be used to project demand for limited health care resources in the region, such as ventilators.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was focused on perception of COVID-19 risk in the Bristol Bay region of rural western Alaska. Every spring, the town of Dillingham, the hub of Bristol Bay fisheries, experiences massive in-migration, as an estimated 13,000 workers arrive for the sockeye salmon fishing season. However, local health care resources and access to transportation were extremely limited. The Region’s only hospital, located in hub town of Dillingham, had only 16 beds, 2 ventilators, and around 37 COVID-19 tests on-hand to serve a regional population of about 7,000 at the time of COVID outbreak.

To Bristol Bay communities, epidemics are part of the local history. After the first World War, several rural communities were decimated by the second wave of the 1918 influenza pandemic, according to Alaska public health officials. In the northern Alaska Nome Census Area, about 10% of the population died due to the outbreak. Later, in the third wave, more than 90% of related influenza deaths in Alaska occurred in Southwest Alaska, which includes the Bristol Bay region. Alaska Native people from this region still have vivid memories of the pandemic. Courtenay Carty, Tribal Administrator of the local Curyung Tribal Council, was quoted in the Anchorage Daily News as saying “the fact that all of our contemporary families are descendants of those children and few adults that survived 1919 is one of (the) major reasons why we are so passionate about protecting ourselves from this pandemic.”

But salmon fishing is the major income source of Bristol Bay residents. Keep the fishing season open? Or, close it?

We are a team of researchers from Pennsylvania State University, University of Alaska Anchorage, and University of Alaska Fairbanks, who have been studying how people adapt to coastal erosion, changing food sources, and changes in environmental risk due to a changing Arctic. In response to the dilemma between COVID-19 risks and income, we have conducted three rounds of surveys (over 2,000 in total) with local residents, decision makers, fishermen and processors to characterize risk perception and vaccine hesitation, evaluate social distancing compliance, and assess perceived costs and benefits of various pandemic mitigation plans.

Overall there was a high level of support (93%) for the opening of the fishery among stakeholders. However, a majority of respondents knew of workers who decided to sit out the season due to COVID-19 risks. Most of the workers perceived a relatively high risk of COVID-19 infection, a large share were concerned about serious illness, and those with co-morbidities perceived a relatively higher COVID-19 health risk.

The perception of Covid risk was highly associated with income, residence and race/ethnicity. Lower income and minority populations demonstrated a relatively higher perception of risk, due in part to known co-morbidity risk factors. However, higher risk populations were more likely to take on more risk because they had relatively fewer opportunities for comparable employment. Respondents with less than median income who are either Hispanic non-resident workers, or Alaska Native residents, had greater concern about exposure to Covid-19, but they viewed the summer fishing season as not easily replaceable work. For non-resident Hispanic workers surveyed in a Bristol Bay Alaska, despite an understanding of the risks of Covid, their noted sentiment that risk of harm was not more important than working, their choices were constrained and they therefore elect to work.

This study increased our understanding of potential amplification or dilution effects from restricting the movement of individuals during a pandemic outbreak. We found the potential to amplify outbreaks in subcommunities by restricting individuals to close quarters with infected individuals, which then shifts the needs for resources from the community as a whole to isolated subpopulations. We also learned more about the tradeoffs between reducing mean infections and reducing the variance in size of a potential outbreak when choosing between competing policy responses.

Due in large part to the high compliance results we reported from the 2020 survey, policy makers decided to change a rule for the 2021 season related to travel. This rule change reduced administrative oversight costs considerably. Compliance remained quite high during the 2021 fishing season. Overall, the results of this project provided timely and insightful information on pandemic perception and vaccination hesitancy, which has helped local decision makers to optimize their resources for tackling pandemic while ensuring safe fishing seasons.
